article.title: Commandant_of_the_Marine_Corps
article.paragraph:
Infobox official postCommandant the Marine Corps {{small|CMC}} FlagCMC.svg{{!}}border{{!}}altborderFlag of the Commandant of the Marine Corps 150px Flag of the Commandant of the Marine Corps
Neller 2015 2.jpg [[General (United States)|General]] [[Robert Neller|Robert B. Neller]] September 24, 2015 [[United States Department of the Navy|Department of the Navy]] [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]]
[[United States Secretary of the Navy|Secretary of the Navy]] [[The Pentagon]], [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington County]], [[Virginia]], U.S. The [[President of the United States|President]] with [[United States Senate|Senate]] [[advice and consent]] 4 years Renewable once (In time of war or during a national emergency declared by Congress) {{UnitedStatesCode|10|5043}}
November 28, 1775''[[de facto]]'',
July 12, 1798''[[de jure]]'' [[Samuel Nicholas]]
[[Assistant Commandant of the Marine Corps]] [http://www.hqmc.marines.mil/cmc/Home.aspx Commandant of the Marine Corps (official website)] TheCommandant of the Marine Corps(CMC) is normally the highest-ranking officer in theUnited States Marine Corpsand is a member of theJoint Chiefs of Staff.UnitedStatesCode10151Joint Chiefs of Staff: composition; functions.The CMC reports directly to theUnited States Secretary of the Navyand is responsible for ensuring the organization, policy, plans, and programs for the Marine Corps as well as advising thePresident of the United StatesPresident, theUnited States Secretary of DefenseSecretary of Defense, theUnited States National Security CouncilNational Security Council,theUnited States Homeland Security CouncilHomeland Security Council,and theUnited States Secretary of the NavySecretary of the Navyon matters involving the Marine Corps. Under the authority of the Secretary of the Navy, the CMC designates Marine personnel and resources to the commanders ofUnified Combatant Commands.UnitedStatesCode10165Combatant commands: administration and supportThe commandant performs all other functions prescribed in Section 5043 inTitle 10 of the United States CodeUnitedStatesCode105043Commandant of the Marine Corpsor delegates those duties and responsibilities to other officers in his administration in his name. As with the other joint chiefs, the Commandant is an administrative position and has no operational command authority over United States Marine Corps forces.

The Commandant is nominated by the President for a four-year term of office and must be confirmed by theUnited States SenateSenate.By statute, the Commandant is appointed as a four-starGeneral (United States)generalwhile serving in office."The Commandant is directly responsible to the Secretary of the Navy for the total performance of the Marine Corps. This includes the administration, discipline, internal organization, training, requirements, efficiency, and readiness of the service. The Commandant is also responsible for the operation of the Marine Corps material support system."cite book2007-05-06 http://www.usmc.mil/units/hqmc/pandr/Documents/Concepts/2006/PDF/Appendicies%202006%20PDFs/2006Appx%20A%20pg252-254%20Intro%20and%20HQMC.pdf Appendix A: How the Marines Are Organized 252 Marine Corps Concepts and Programs 2006 United States Marine Corps PDFSince 1801, the official residence of the Commandant has been located in theMarine Barracks, Washington, D.C.Marine BarracksinWashington, D.C.and his main offices are inArlington County, Virginia.
article.heading: Responsibilities
article.paragraph: The responsibilities of the Commandant are outlined in Title 10, Section 5043 theUnited States Codeand is "Subject to the authority, direction, and control of theUnited States Secretary of the NavySecretary of the Navy". As stated in the U.S. Code, the Commandant shall preside over the Headquarters, Marine Corps, transmit the plans and recommendations of the Headquarters, Marine Corps, to the Secretary and advise the Secretary with regard to such plans and recommendations, after approval of the plans or recommendations of the Headquarters, Marine Corps, by the Secretary, act as the agent of the Secretary in carrying them into effect, exercise supervision, consistent with the authority assigned to commanders of unified or specified combatant commands under chapter 6 of this title, over such of the members and organizations of the Marine Corps and the Navy as the Secretary determines, perform the duties prescribed for him by section 171 of this title and other provisions of law and perform such other military duties, not otherwise assigned by law, as are assigned to him by the President, theUnited States Secretary of DefenseSecretary of Defense, or the Secretary of the Navy.
article.heading: List of commandants
article.paragraph: Thirty-sevencite web2007-10-21 http://www.tecom.usmc.mil/HD/Frequently_Requested/Commandants.htm Commandants of the U.S. Marine Corps Historical Topics: Frequently Requested Reference Branch, [[United States Marine Corps History Division|History Division, United States Marine Corps]]men have served as the Commandant of the Marine Corps. The first Commandant wasSamuel Nicholas, who took office as aCaptain (United States O-3)captain,though there was no office titled "Commandant" at the time, and theSecond Continental Congresshad authorized that the senior-most Marine could take a rank up toColonel (United States)Colonel.cite webhttp://www.tecom.usmc.mil/HD/Docs_Speeches/Continentialcongressestmarines1775.htmResolution Establishing the Continental MarinesJournal of the Continental Congress10 November 1775[[United States Marine Corps History Division]]2 February 2010The longest-serving wasArchibald Henderson, sometimes referred to as the "Grand old man of the Marine Corps" due to his thirty-nine-year tenure.In the 236-year history of theUnited States Marine Corps, only one Commandant has ever been fired from the job:Anthony Gale, as a result of acourt-martialin 1820.

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of Samuel Nicholas

tablerow.tablecell: The firstde factoCommandant for his role as the senior-most officer of theContinental Marines.cite bookHoffmanCol Jon T.Beth L. Crumley (illustration editor), Charles J. Ziga (design), Col John Greenwood (editor), James O. Muschett (editor)USMC: A Complete History[[Marine Corps Association]]Hugh Lauter Levin Associates20020-88363-650-6http://www.mca-marines.org/gazette/bookindex02.asp

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of William W. Burrows

tablerow.tablecell: The firstde jureCommandant, he started many important organizations within the Marine Corps, including theUnited States Marine Band

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of Franklin Wharton

tablerow.tablecell: The first Commandant to be court-martialed (acquitted) and the first to occupy the Commandant's House at theMarine Barracks, Washington, D.C.

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of Archibald Henderson

tablerow.tablecell: Henderson1Archibald Henderson(acting)
Acting Commandant, would later serve as Commandant from 1820 to 1859
The second Commandant to be court-martialed and the only Commandant to be fired. Burial location is unknown and no photos have ever been located.

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of Archibald Henderson

tablerow.tablecell: The longest-serving Commandant; known as the "Grand old man of the Marine Corps"; known for his role in expanding the Marine Corps' mission to includeexpeditionary warfareandRapid deployment forcerapid deploymentcite journalKrivdoMichael E.4th quarter 2009Harpers Ferry: Last Action of "Henderson Era"FortitudineUnited States Marine Corps Historical Program[[Marine Corps Base Quantico|Quantico]], VA344pp. 7–110-16-010404-1http://bookstore.gpo.gov/actions/GetPublication.do?stocknumber2010-02-01

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of John Harris

tablerow.tablecell: Commandant during most of theAmerican Civil War

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Jacob Zeilin

tablerow.tablecell: Became the Marine Corps' firstgeneral officer, officially approved of the design of theEagle, Globe, and Anchoras the emblem of the Marine Corps

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Charles G. McCawley

tablerow.tablecell: Chose "Semper fidelisSemper Fidelis", Latin for "Always Faithful", as the official Marine Corps motto

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of Charles Heywood

tablerow.tablecell: Was the first Marine to hold the rank ofMajor general (United States)Major General

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of George F. Elliott

tablerow.tablecell: Successfully resisted attempts to remove seagoing Marines fromcapital shipsand to merge the Corps into theUnited States Army

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of William P. Biddle

tablerow.tablecell: Established theAdvanced Base Force, forerunner of today'sFleet Marine Force

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of George Barnett

tablerow.tablecell: Served as Commandant duringWorld War I, which caused a huge increase in personnel during his term

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of John A. Lejeune

tablerow.tablecell: Started the tradition of theUnited States Marine Corps birthday ballbirthday ballwith Marine Corps Order 47, still read annually. Commanded a US Army division (the 2nd Infantry Division) in combat during World War I.

link.part: alt=black & white portrait of Wendall C. Neville

tablerow.tablecell: Recipient of theMedal of HonorandMarine Corps Brevet Medal

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Ben H. Fuller

tablerow.tablecell: Consolidated theFleet Marine Forceconcept

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of John H. Russell, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: The system of seniority promotions of officers was changed to advancement by selection, the 1st Marine Brigade was withdrawn from Haiti, and the number of ships carrying Marine detachments continued to increase.

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Thomas Holcomb

tablerow.tablecell: Expanded the Corps almost 20 times in size forWorld War IIand integrated women into the Corps. The first Marine to be advanced (after retirement) to the rank ofGeneral (United States)General

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Alexander A. Vandegrift

tablerow.tablecell: Recipient of theMedal of Honor. Was the first active duty Marine to hold the rank ofGeneral (United States)General, resisted attempts to merge the Corps with theUnited States ArmyArmy

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Clifton B. Cates

tablerow.tablecell: Recipient of theNavy Cross. Commandant during early stage of theKorean War.

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Lemuel C. Shepherd, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: First Commandant to serve on theJoint Chiefs of Staff. Commandant during theKorean War.

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Randolph M. Pate

tablerow.tablecell: Commandant between U.S. involvement in theKorean WarandVietnam War.

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of David M. Shoup

tablerow.tablecell: Recipient of theMedal of Honor. Opposed U.S. involvement in South Vietnam based on strategy and undue influence of corporations and military officials in foreign policy. Historians consider Shoup's criticisms to be among the most pointed and high-profile leveled by a veteran against the Vietnam War.

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Wallace M. Greene, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: Oversaw the proliferation of the Corps in theVietnam War

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Leonard F. Chapman, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: Was the Commandant during the final years of U.S. involvement in theVietnam War. Chapman witnessed the III Marine Amphibious Force withdrawal from Vietnam and the strength of the Corps drop from a peak of 289,000 to 198,000.

link.part: alt=black & white photograph of Robert Everton Cushman, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: Saw the last of the Marines leaveVietnamand the peacetime strength fall to 194,000 while still maintaining readiness

link.part: alt=Color of Louis H. Wilson, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: Recipient of theMedal of HonorforBattle of Guam (1944)capture of Guam

link.part: alt=color photograph of Robert H. Barrow

tablerow.tablecell: Last World War II veteran to be Commandant. Was the first Commandant to serve as a full member of theJoint Chiefs of Staff, acquired approval of production of the American-modifiedHawker Siddeley HarrierHarrier aircraft, and several other improvements to enhance the effectiveness of the Marine Corps

link.part: alt=Color photograph of Paul X. Kelley

tablerow.tablecell: Commandant when the Marine Barracks bombing occurred in Beirut during the 1982-84 multinational force peacekeeping mission under the Reagan Administration. In 2007, General Kelley published in theWashington Postan opinion piece that had a negative opinion on the use ofenhanced interrogation techniques

link.target: File:Alfred Gray, official military photo color.JPEG
link.part: alt=color photograph of Alfred M. Gray, Jr., the only Marine in this list wearing utilities instead of a service or dress uniform

tablerow.tablecell:
The Alfred M. Gray Research Center atMarine Corps Base Quanticohouses the Marine Corps Archives and Special Collections, the Quantico Base Library, and the research library for theMarine Corps University.
As a reminder that the primary role of every Marine is a rifleman, he had his official photograph taken in the Camouflage UtilityUniforms of the United States Marine CorpsUniform, the only Commandant to have done so.

link.part: alt=color photograph of Carl E. Mundy, Jr.

tablerow.tablecell: After retirement, he served as president and CEO of theUnited Service Organizations(USO), and was the chairman of theMarine Corps UniversityFoundation.

link.part: alt=color photograph of Charles C. Krulak

tablerow.tablecell: Was the son of Marine Corps Lieutenant GeneralVictor H. Krulak. Came up with the concept of the 'Strategic Corporal' and the 'Three Block War'. IntroducedUnited States Marine Corps Recruit Training#The CrucibleThe Crucible, a final test of Marine recruits.

link.part: alt=color photograph of James L. Jones

tablerow.tablecell: Oversaw the Marine Corps' development ofMARPATMarine Corps Combat Utility Uniformcamouflage uniformsand the adoption of theMarine Corps Martial Arts Program; later became the first Marine officer to serve as Commander,United States European CommandU.S. European Command(USEUCOM) andNATO'sSupreme Headquarters Allied Powers EuropeSupreme Allied Commander Europe(SACEUR), then asNational Security Advisor (United States)National Security Advisorfor theObama Administration.

link.part: alt=color photograph of Michael W. Hagee

tablerow.tablecell: Guided the Corps through the initial years of theIraq War

link.target: File:James T. Conway, official military photo portrait, 2006.jpg
link.part: alt=color photograph of James T. Conway

tablerow.tablecell:
Commanded Marines forces in the Iraq War and oversaw expansion of the Corps to 202,000 personnel.
First Commandant in nearly 40 years to have not served in the Vietnam War.

FirstUnited States Naval Aviatorto serve as Commandant.cite webhttp://www.marines.mil/unit/barracks/Pages /TakingthereinsMarineCorpswelcomesnewcommandant.aspxTaking the Reins: Marine Corps Welcomes New CommandantSheaSgt Jimmy D.22 October 2010[[Headquarters Marine Corps]]United States Marine Corps22 October 2010
First Commandant to be promoted toChairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staffand second marine overall.
Incumbent
